Description: Body sherd (mended from six fragments) of Attic red-figured pottery bell-krater with turn to rim; interior glazed black with reserved band; exterior: part of reserved band at junction of rim and body (shallow and carinated step); below, red-figure decoration consisting of Eros (head, right arm and wing lost, with a faded fillet hanging from his lost right hand) flying to right and looking back; on right, Poseidon (lower legs lost, with a piece of drapery between his knees and added white wreath with added miltos) seated three-quarters to left and holding a trident in his left hand; below, head and arms and part of tail of Triton (white wreath with added miltos) swimming up, to right; relief-contour except for hands.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford G138.45a and b. Beazley suggests that the picture perhaps represented Theseus visiting Poseidon.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0221) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain Fasc. 3, Oxford Fasc. 1 (p. 46, pl. L, no. 25)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
